description: From Middle French adopter, from Latin adoptō; ad +‎ optō (“to choose, desire”), equivalent to ad- +‎ opt.

verbs.description: adopt (third-person singular simple present adopts, present participle adopting, simple past and past participle adopted) (transitive)

definitionGroups.group: To take (a child, heir, friend, citizen, etc.) by choice into a relationship.

entries.meaning: To take voluntarily (a child of other parents) to be in the place of, or as, one's own child.
examples: A friend of mine recently adopted a Chinese baby girl found on the streets of Beijing.

entries.meaning: To obtain (a pet) from a shelter or the wild.
examples: We're going to adopt a Dalmatian.

entries.meaning: To take by choice into the scope of one's responsibility.
examples: This supermarket chain adopts several families every Yuletide, providing them with money and groceries for the holidays.

entries.meaning: To take or receive as one's own what is not so naturally.
examples: He adopted a new look in order to fit in with his new workmates.

entries.meaning: To select and take or approve.
examples: to adopt the view or policy of another
These are resolutions that were adopted.

entries.meaning: (chess, slang) To beat an opponent ten times in a row.
examples: The match was not even close; the IM made amateurish blunders and ended up getting adopted.
